The Cape of Good Hope looking towards the west, from the coastal cliffs above
Cape Point, overlooking Dias beach

The **Cape of Good Hope** ([Afrikaans](/wiki/Afrikaans_language "Afrikaans
language"): _Kaap die Goeie Hoop_ [[ˌkɑːp di ˌχujə
ˈɦʊəp]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Afrikaans "Help:IPA/Afrikaans"),
[Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language"): _Kaap de Goede Hoop_ [[ˌkaːb
də ˌɣudə ˈɦoːp]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Dutch "Help:IPA/Dutch") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Nl-Kaap_de_Goede_Hoop.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/70/Nl-
Kaap_de_Goede_Hoop.ogg "Nl-Kaap de Goede Hoop.ogg")),[1]
[Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): _Cabo da Boa
Esperança_ [[ˈkaβu ðɐ ˈβoɐ ʃpɨˈɾɐ̃sɐ]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese
"Help:IPA/Portuguese")) is a rocky [headland](/wiki/Headlands_and_bays
"Headlands and bays") on the [Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean")
coast of the [Cape Peninsula](/wiki/Cape_Peninsula "Cape Peninsula") in [South
Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa").

A common misconception is that the Cape of Good Hope is the southern tip of
[Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa"). This misconception was based on the misbelief
that the Cape was the dividing point between the
[Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") and [Indian
Oceans](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean"). Contemporary geographic knowledge
instead states the southernmost point of Africa is [Cape
Agulhas](/wiki/Cape_Agulhas "Cape Agulhas") about 150 kilometres (90 mi) to
the [east-southeast](/wiki/East-southeast "East-southeast").[2] The currents
of the two oceans meet at the point where the warm-water [Agulhas
current](/wiki/Agulhas_current "Agulhas current") meets the cold-water
[Benguela current](/wiki/Benguela_current "Benguela current") and turns back
on itself. That oceanic meeting point fluctuates between Cape Agulhas and
[Cape Point](/wiki/Cape_Point "Cape Point") (about 1.2 kilometres (0.75 mi)
east of the Cape of Good Hope).

[Wikimedia](https://foundation.wikimedia.org/wiki/Maps_Terms_of_Use) | © [OpenStreetMap](https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright)

The Cape of Good Hope is at the southern tip of the [Cape
Peninsula](/wiki/Cape_Peninsula "Cape Peninsula") approximately 50 km (31 mi)
south of [Cape Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"), [South
Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa").

When following the western side of the African coastline from the equator,
however, the Cape of Good Hope marks the point where a ship begins to travel
more eastward than southward. Thus, the first modern rounding of the cape in
1488 by [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_discoveries "Portuguese discoveries")
explorer [Bartolomeu Dias](/wiki/Bartolomeu_Dias "Bartolomeu Dias") was a
milestone in the attempts by the Portuguese to establish direct trade
relations with the [Far East](/wiki/Far_East "Far East") (although
[Herodotus](/wiki/Herodotus "Herodotus") mentioned a claim that the
[Phoenicians](/wiki/Phoenicia "Phoenicia") had done so [far
earlier](/wiki/Necho_II#Phoenician_expedition "Necho II")).[3] Dias called the
cape _Cabo das Tormentas_ ("Cape of Storms"; [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language
"Dutch language"): _Stormkaap_), which was the original name of the "Cape of
Good Hope".[4]

As one of the [great capes](/wiki/Great_capes "Great capes") of the South
Atlantic Ocean, the Cape of Good Hope has long been of special significance to
sailors, many of whom refer to it simply as "**the Cape** ".[5] It is a
[waypoint](/wiki/Waypoint "Waypoint") on the [Cape Route](/wiki/Cape_Route
"Cape Route") and the [clipper route](/wiki/Clipper_route "Clipper route")
followed by [clipper ships](/wiki/Clipper_ship "Clipper ship") to the [Far
East](/wiki/Far_East "Far East") and [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"),
and still followed by several offshore [yacht races](/wiki/Yacht_racing "Yacht
racing").

The term _Cape of Good Hope_ is also used in three other ways:

  * It is a section of the [Table Mountain National Park](/wiki/Table_Mountain_National_Park "Table Mountain National Park"), within which the cape of the same name, as well as [Cape Point](/wiki/Cape_Point "Cape Point"), falls. Prior to its incorporation into the national park, this section constituted the Cape Point Nature Reserve.[6]
  * It was the name of the early [Cape Colony](/wiki/Cape_Colony "Cape Colony") established by the Dutch in 1652, on the [Cape Peninsula](/wiki/Cape_Peninsula "Cape Peninsula").
  * Just before the [Union of South Africa](/wiki/Union_of_South_Africa "Union of South Africa") was formed, the term referred to the entire region that in 1910 was to become the [Cape of Good Hope Province](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope_Province "Cape of Good Hope Province") (usually shortened to _the Cape Province_).

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_of_Good_Hope&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

[Eudoxus of Cyzicus](/wiki/Eudoxus_of_Cyzicus "Eudoxus of Cyzicus")
([/ˈjuːdəksəs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English");
[Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Εὔδοξος, _Eúdoxos_ ; fl. c.
130 BC) was a [Greek](/wiki/Ethnic_Greek "Ethnic Greek")
[navigator](/wiki/Navigator "Navigator") for [Ptolemy
VIII](/wiki/Ptolemy_VIII_Physcon "Ptolemy VIII Physcon"), king of the
[Hellenistic](/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization "Hellenistic civilization")
[Ptolemaic dynasty](/wiki/Ptolemaic_dynasty "Ptolemaic dynasty") in
[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"), who found the wreck of a ship in the [Indian
Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") that appeared to have come from
[Gades](/wiki/C%C3%A1diz "Cádiz") (today's [Cádiz](/wiki/C%C3%A1diz "Cádiz")
in Spain), rounding the Cape.

When Eudoxus was returning from his second voyage to India the wind forced him
south of the [Gulf of Aden](/wiki/Gulf_of_Aden "Gulf of Aden") and down the
coast of Africa for some distance. Somewhere along the coast of East Africa,
he found the remains of the ship. Due to its appearance and the story told by
the natives, Eudoxus concluded that the ship was from Gades and had sailed
anti-clockwise around Africa, passing the Cape and entering the Indian Ocean.
This inspired him to repeat the voyage and attempt a
[circumnavigation](/wiki/Circumnavigation "Circumnavigation") of the
continent. Organising the expedition on his own account he set sail from Gades
and began to work down the African coast. The difficulties were too great,
however, and he was obliged to return to Europe.[7]

After this failure he again set out to circumnavigate Africa. His eventual
fate is unknown. Although some, such as [Pliny](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny
the Elder"), claimed that Eudoxus did achieve his goal, the most probable
conclusion is that he perished on the journey.[8]

In the 1450 [Fra Mauro map](/wiki/Fra_Mauro_map "Fra Mauro map"), the Indian
Ocean is depicted as connected to the Atlantic. Fra Mauro puts the following
inscription by the southern tip of Africa, which he names the "Cape of Diab",
describing the exploration by a ship from the East around 1420:[9][10]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/FraMauroChineseShip.jpg/220px-
FraMauroChineseShip.jpg)](/wiki/File:FraMauroChineseShip.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FraMauroChineseShip.jpg "Enlarge")

Detail of the Fra Mauro Map describing the construction of the junks that
navigate in the Indian Ocean.

> "Around 1420 a ship, or junk, from India crossed the Sea of India towards
> the Island of Men and the Island of Women, off Cape Diab, between the Green
> Islands and the shadows. It sailed for 40 days in a south-westerly direction
> without ever finding anything other than wind and water. According to these
> people themselves, the ship went some 2,000 miles ahead until - once
> favourable conditions came to an end - it turned round and sailed back to
> Cape Diab in 70 days".

> "The ships called junks (lit. "Zonchi") that navigate these seas carry four
> masts or more, some of which can be raised or lowered, and have 40 to 60
> cabins for the merchants and only one tiller. They can navigate without a
> [compass](/wiki/Compass "Compass"), because they have an
> [astrologer](/wiki/Astrologer "Astrologer"), who stands on the side and,
> with an [astrolabe](/wiki/Astrolabe "Astrolabe") in hand, gives orders to
> the navigator". (Text from the Fra Mauro map, 09-P25.)

Fra Mauro explained that he obtained the information from "a trustworthy
source", who traveled with the expedition, possibly the Venetian explorer
[Niccolò da Conti](/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_da_Conti "Niccolò da Conti") who
happened to be in [Calicut](/wiki/Kozhikode "Kozhikode"), [India](/wiki/India
"India") at the time the expedition left:

> "What is more, I have spoken with a person worthy of trust, who says that he
> sailed in an Indian ship caught in the fury of a tempest for 40 days out in
> the Sea of India, beyond the [Cape of Soffala](/wiki/Sofala "Sofala") and
> the Green Islands towards west-southwest; and according to the astrologers
> who act as their guides, they had advanced almost 2,000 miles. Thus one can
> believe and confirm what is said by both these and those, and that they had
> therefore sailed 4,000 miles".

Fra Mauro also comments that the account of the expedition, together with the
relation by [Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo") of the travels of [Eudoxus of
Cyzicus](/wiki/Eudoxus_of_Cyzicus "Eudoxus of Cyzicus") from
[Arabia](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula "Arabian Peninsula") to
[Gibraltar](/wiki/Gibraltar "Gibraltar") through the southern Ocean in
[Antiquity](/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical antiquity"), led him to
believe that the [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") was not a
closed sea and that [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa") could be circumnavigated
by her southern end (Text from Fra Mauro map, 11, G2). This knowledge,
together with the map depiction of the African continent, probably encouraged
the Portuguese to intensify their effort to round the tip of Africa.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Cape_Peninsula.jpg/300px-
Cape_Peninsula.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cape_Peninsula.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cape_Peninsula.jpg "Enlarge")

Map showing the [Cape Peninsula](/wiki/Cape_Peninsula "Cape Peninsula"),
illustrating the position of the Cape of Good Hope. The main mountains and
their peaks, including [Table Mountain](/wiki/Table_Mountain "Table
Mountain"), and its relation to the City of [Cape Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape
Town") are shown.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/CapeHopeDetail.png/300px-
CapeHopeDetail.png)](/wiki/File:CapeHopeDetail.png)

[](/wiki/File:CapeHopeDetail.png "Enlarge")

Map of the Cape of Good Hope and [Cape Agulhas](/wiki/Cape_Agulhas "Cape
Agulhas") the southernmost point of Africa.

Main article: [Cape Colony](/wiki/Cape_Colony "Cape Colony")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Cross_daGama2.jpg/170px-
Cross_daGama2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cross_daGama2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cross_daGama2.jpg "Enlarge")

Reproduction of the Cross of [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da
Gama") at the Cape of Good Hope.

In the [Early Modern Era](/wiki/Early_Modern_Era "Early Modern Era"), the
first European to reach the cape was the Portuguese explorer [Bartolomeu
Dias](/wiki/Bartolomeu_Dias "Bartolomeu Dias") on 12 March 1488, who named it
the "Cape of Storms" (_Cabo das Tormentas_). It was later renamed by [John II
of Portugal](/wiki/John_II_of_Portugal "John II of Portugal") as "Cape of Good
Hope" (_Cabo da Boa Esperança_) because of the great optimism engendered by
the opening of a sea route to [India](/wiki/India "India") and the East.

The [Khoikhoi](/wiki/Khoikhoi "Khoikhoi") people lived in the cape area when
the Dutch first settled there in 1652. The Khoikhoi had arrived in this area
about fifteen hundred years before.[11] The Dutch called them
[Hottentots](/wiki/Khoikhoi "Khoikhoi"), a term that has now come to be
regarded as pejorative.

[Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") colonial administrator [Jan van
Riebeeck](/wiki/Jan_van_Riebeeck "Jan van Riebeeck") established a resupply
camp for the [Dutch East India Company](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company "Dutch
East India Company") some 50 km north of the cape in [Table
Bay](/wiki/Table_Bay "Table Bay") on 6 April 1652 and this eventually
developed into [Cape Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"). Supplies of fresh
food were vital on the long journey around Africa and Cape Town became known
as "The Tavern of the Seas".

On 31 December 1687 a community of [Huguenots](/wiki/Huguenots "Huguenots")
(French Protestants) arrived at the Cape of Good Hope from the Netherlands.
They had escaped from France and fled to the Netherlands to flee religious
persecution in France. One example was Pierre Joubert who came from [La
Motte-d'Aigues](/wiki/La_Motte-d%27Aigues "La Motte-d'Aigues"). The Dutch East
India Company needed skilled farmers at the Cape of Good Hope and the Dutch
Government saw opportunities to settle Huguenots at the Cape and sent them
there. The Cape colony gradually grew over the next 150 years or so until it
stretched for hundreds of kilometres to the north and north-east.

During the Napoleonic Wars, the Dutch Republic was occupied by the French in
1795. Thus the Cape Colony became a French vassal and enemy of the British.
Therefore, the United Kingdom invaded and occupied the Cape Colony that same
year. The British relinquished control of the territory in 1803 but returned
and reoccupied the Colony on 19 January 1806 following the [Battle of
Blaauwberg](/wiki/Battle_of_Blaauwberg "Battle of Blaauwberg"). The Dutch
ceded the territory to the British in the [Anglo-Dutch Treaty of
1814](/wiki/Anglo-Dutch_Treaty_of_1814 "Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1814") The Cape
was then administered as the [Cape Colony](/wiki/Cape_Colony "Cape Colony")
and it remained a British colony until it was incorporated into the
independent [Union of South Africa](/wiki/Union_of_South_Africa "Union of
South Africa") in 1910 (now known as the Republic of South Africa).

The Portuguese government erected two navigational beacons, **Dias Cross** and
**Gama Cross** , to commemorate [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da
Gama") and [Bartolomeu Dias](/wiki/Bartolomeu_Dias "Bartolomeu Dias") as
explorers who as mentioned were the first explorers to reach the cape. When
lined up, the crosses point to Whittle Rock ([34°21′24.63″S 18°28′26.36″E﻿ /
﻿34.3568417°S 18.4739889°E﻿ / -34.3568417;
18.4739889](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Cape_of_Good_Hope&params=34_21_24.63_S_18_28_26.36_E_)),
a large, permanently submerged shipping hazard in [False Bay](/wiki/False_Bay
"False Bay"). Two other beacons in [Simon's Town](/wiki/Simon%27s_Town
"Simon's Town") provide the intersection.

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_of_Good_Hope&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Geography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Cape_of_Good_Hope_sign_%2801%29.jpg/220px-
Cape_of_Good_Hope_sign_%2801%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cape_of_Good_Hope_sign_\(01\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cape_of_Good_Hope_sign_\(01\).jpg "Enlarge")

Sign at the Cape of Good Hope, 2018

The Cape of Good Hope is at the southern tip of the [Cape
Peninsula](/wiki/Cape_Peninsula "Cape Peninsula"), about 2.3 kilometres (1.4
mi) west and a little south of [Cape Point](/wiki/Cape_Point "Cape Point") on
the south-east corner. [Cape Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town") is about 50
kilometres to the north of the Cape, in [Table Bay](/wiki/Table_Bay "Table
Bay") at the north end of the peninsula. The peninsula forms the western
boundary of [False Bay](/wiki/False_Bay "False Bay"). Geologically, the rocks
found at the two capes, and indeed over much of the peninsula, are part of the
[Cape Supergroup](/wiki/Cape_Peninsula#Geology "Cape Peninsula"), and are
formed of the same type of sandstones as [Table
Mountain](/wiki/Table_Mountain_\(South_Africa\) "Table Mountain \(South
Africa\)") itself. Both the Cape of Good Hope and [Cape
Point](/wiki/Cape_Point "Cape Point") offer spectacular scenery; the whole of
the southernmost portion of the Cape Peninsula is a wild, rugged, scenic and
generally unspoiled national park.

The term _the Cape_ has also been used in a wider sense, to indicate the area
of [the European colony](/wiki/Cape_Colony "Cape Colony") centred on [Cape
Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"), and the later [South African
province](/wiki/Cape_Province "Cape Province"). Since 1994, it has been broken
up into three smaller provinces: the [Western Cape](/wiki/Western_Cape
"Western Cape"), [Eastern Cape](/wiki/Eastern_Cape "Eastern Cape") and
[Northern Cape](/wiki/Northern_Cape "Northern Cape"); parts of the province
were also absorbed into the [North
West](/wiki/North_West_\(South_African_province\) "North West \(South African
province\)").

## Fauna[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_of_Good_Hope&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Fauna")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Avestruz_de_cuello_azul_%28Struthio_camelus_australis%29%2C_cabo_de_Buena_Esparanza%2C_Sud%C3%A1frica%2C_2018-07-23%2C_DD_85.jpg/220px-
Avestruz_de_cuello_azul_%28Struthio_camelus_australis%29%2C_cabo_de_Buena_Esparanza%2C_Sud%C3%A1frica%2C_2018-07-23%2C_DD_85.jpg)](/wiki/File:Avestruz_de_cuello_azul_\(Struthio_camelus_australis\),_cabo_de_Buena_Esparanza,_Sud%C3%A1frica,_2018-07-23,_DD_85.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Avestruz_de_cuello_azul_\(Struthio_camelus_australis\),_cabo_de_Buena_Esparanza,_Sud%C3%A1frica,_2018-07-23,_DD_85.jpg
"Enlarge")

Male [ostrich](/wiki/Ostrich "Ostrich") at the Cape of Good Hope

With its diverse habitat, ranging from rocky mountain tops to beaches and open
sea, the Cape of Good Hope is home to at least 250 species of birds including
one of the two mainland colonies of [African
penguins](/wiki/Spheniscus_demersus "Spheniscus demersus").

"Bush birds" tend to be rather scarce because of the coarse, scrubby nature of
[fynbos](/wiki/Fynbos "Fynbos") vegetation. When flowering, however,
[proteas](/wiki/Protea "Protea") and [ericas](/wiki/Erica "Erica") attract
[sunbirds](/wiki/Sunbird "Sunbird"), [sugarbirds](/wiki/Sugarbird
"Sugarbird"), and other species in search of nectar. For most of the year,
there are more small birds in coastal thicket than in fynbos.

The Cape of Good Hope section of Table Mountain National Park is home to
several species of antelope. Bontebok and eland are easily seen, and [red
hartebeest](/wiki/Red_hartebeest "Red hartebeest") can be seen in the grazing
lawns in Smitswinkel Flats. Grey rhebok are less commonly seen and are scarce,
but may be observed along the beach hills at Olifantsbos. Most visitors are
unlikely to ever see either Cape grysbok or klipspringer.

The Cape of Good Hope section is home to four [Cape mountain
zebra](/wiki/Cape_mountain_zebra "Cape mountain zebra"). They might be seen by
the attentive or lucky visitor, usually in Smitswinkel Flats.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Rock_hyrax_at_Cape_of_Good_Hope.jpg/220px-
Rock_hyrax_at_Cape_of_Good_Hope.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rock_hyrax_at_Cape_of_Good_Hope.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rock_hyrax_at_Cape_of_Good_Hope.jpg "Enlarge")

[Dassie](/wiki/Rock_hyrax "Rock hyrax") at the Cape of Good Hope

There are a wealth of small animals such as [lizards](/wiki/Lizard "Lizard"),
[snakes](/wiki/Snake "Snake"), [tortoises](/wiki/Tortoise "Tortoise") and
[insects](/wiki/Insect "Insect"). Small mammals include [rock
hyrax](/wiki/Rock_hyrax "Rock hyrax"), [four-striped grass mouse](/wiki/Four-
striped_grass_mouse "Four-striped grass mouse"), [water
mongoose](/wiki/Marsh_mongoose "Marsh mongoose"), [Cape clawless
otter](/wiki/Cape_clawless_otter "Cape clawless otter") and [fallow
deer](/wiki/Fallow_deer "Fallow deer").

The area offers excellent vantage points for whale watching. The [southern
right whale](/wiki/Southern_right_whale "Southern right whale") is the species
most likely to be seen in [False Bay](/wiki/False_Bay "False Bay") between
June and November. Other species are the [humpback whale](/wiki/Humpback_whale
"Humpback whale") and [Bryde's whale](/wiki/Bryde%27s_whale "Bryde's whale").
[Seals](/wiki/Pinniped "Pinniped"), [dusky dolphins](/wiki/Dusky_dolphin
"Dusky dolphin") and [killer whales](/wiki/Killer_whale "Killer whale") have
also been seen.

The strategic position of the Cape of Good Hope between two major ocean
currents, ensures a rich diversity of marine life. There is a difference
between the sea life west of Cape Point and that to the east due to the
markedly differing sea temperatures.

The South African Marine Living Resources Act is strictly enforced throughout
the [Table Mountain National Park](/wiki/Table_Mountain_National_Park "Table
Mountain National Park"), and especially in marine protected areas.
Disturbance or removal of any marine organisms is strictly prohibited between
Schusters Bay and Hoek van Bobbejaan, but is allowed in other areas during
season and with relevant permits.

### Chacma
baboons[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_of_Good_Hope&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Chacma baboons")]

Chacma baboons (_[Papio ursinus](/wiki/Papio_ursinus "Papio ursinus")_) are
the mammals most intimately associated with the Cape of Good Hope. Baboons
inside the Cape of Good Hope section of the park are a major tourist
attraction. There are 11 troops consisting of about 375 individuals throughout
the entire Cape Peninsula. Six of these 11 troops either live entirely within
the Cape of Good Hope section of the park, or use the section as part of their
range. The Cape Point, Kanonkop, Klein Olifantsbos, and Buffels Bay troops
live entirely inside the Cape of Good Hope section of the Park. The Groot
Olifantsbos and Plateau Road troops range into the park.

Chacma baboons are widely distributed across southern Africa and are
classified as ″least concern" in the [_IUCN Red List of Threatened
Species_](http://www.iucnredlist.org/apps/redlist/details/full/16022/0).
However, the South African Parks Department states in its publication
_Mountains in the Sea_ that the baboon population on the Cape is "critically
endangered." This is due to habitat loss, genetic isolation, and conflicts
with humans. Cape baboons have been eliminated from the majority of their
range across the Cape Peninsula, and the Cape of Good Hope section of Table
Mountain National Park provides a sanctuary for the troops that live within
its boundaries. It provides relative safety from nearby towns, where people
have killed many baboons after the baboons raid their houses looking for food.
Baboons are also frequently injured or killed outside of the park by cars and
by electrocution on power lines. Inside the park, some management policies
such as allowing barbecues and picnics in the baboon home ranges cause
detriment to the troops, as they become embroiled in conflicts with guests to
the park.

## Flora[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_of_Good_Hope&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Flora")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flora_at_Cape_Peninsula.JPG/220px-
Flora_at_Cape_Peninsula.JPG)](/wiki/File:Flora_at_Cape_Peninsula.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Flora_at_Cape_Peninsula.JPG "Enlarge")

[Fynbos](/wiki/Fynbos "Fynbos") at Cape Peninsula

The Cape of Good Hope is an integral part of the [Cape Floristic
Kingdom](/wiki/Cape_Floristic_Kingdom "Cape Floristic Kingdom"), the smallest
but richest of the world's six floral kingdoms. This comprises a treasure
trove of 1100 species of indigenous plants, of which a number are
[endemic](/wiki/Endemism "Endemism") (occur naturally nowhere else on earth).
The main type of [fynbos](/wiki/Fynbos "Fynbos") ("fine bush") vegetation at
the Cape of Good Hope is [Peninsula Sandstone
Fynbos](/wiki/Peninsula_Sandstone_Fynbos "Peninsula Sandstone Fynbos"), an
endangered vegetation type that is endemic to the Cape Peninsula. Coastal
[Hangklip Sand Fynbos](/wiki/Hangklip_Sand_Fynbos "Hangklip Sand Fynbos")
grows on low-lying alkaline sands and, right by the sea, small patches of
[Cape Flats Dune Strandveld](/wiki/Cape_Flats_Dune_Strandveld "Cape Flats Dune
Strandveld") can be found.[12][13]

Characteristic fynbos plants include [proteas](/wiki/Protea "Protea"),
[ericas](/wiki/Erica "Erica") (heath), and [restios](/wiki/Restio "Restio")
(reeds). Some of the most striking and well-known members belong to the
[Proteacae](/wiki/Proteacae "Proteacae") family, of which up to 24 species
occur. These include [king protea](/wiki/King_protea "King protea"),
[sugarbush](/wiki/Protea "Protea"), [tree pincushion](/wiki/Tree_pincushion
"Tree pincushion") and golden [cone bush](/wiki/Cone_bush "Cone bush")
(_[Leucadendron](/wiki/Leucadendron "Leucadendron") laureolum_).

Many popular horticultural plants like [pelargoniums](/wiki/Pelargonium
"Pelargonium"), [freesias](/wiki/Freesia "Freesia"),
[daisies](/wiki/Asteraceae "Asteraceae"), [lilies](/wiki/Lily "Lily") and
[irises](/wiki/Iris_\(plant\) "Iris \(plant\)") also have their origins in
fynbos.

## Legends[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_of_Good_Hope&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Legends")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Playa_Dias%2C_Cape_Point%2C_Sud%C3%A1frica%2C_2018-07-23%2C_DD_93-99_PAN.jpg/860px-
Playa_Dias%2C_Cape_Point%2C_Sud%C3%A1frica%2C_2018-07-23%2C_DD_93-99_PAN.jpg)](/wiki/File:Playa_Dias,_Cape_Point,_Sud%C3%A1frica,_2018-07-23,_DD_93-99_PAN.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Playa_Dias,_Cape_Point,_Sud%C3%A1frica,_2018-07-23,_DD_93-99_PAN.jpg
"Enlarge")

Cape of Good Hope panorama

  * The Cape of Good Hope is the legendary home of _[The Flying Dutchman](/wiki/The_Flying_Dutchman "The Flying Dutchman")_. Crewed by tormented and damned ghostly sailors, it is doomed forever to beat its way through the adjacent waters without ever succeeding in rounding the headland.
  * _[Adamastor](/wiki/Adamastor "Adamastor")_ is a Greek-type mythological character invented by the Portuguese poet [Luís de Camões](/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_de_Cam%C3%B5es "Luís de Camões") in his epic poem _[Os Lusíadas](/wiki/Os_Lus%C3%ADadas "Os Lusíadas")_ (first printed in 1572), as a symbol of the forces of nature Portuguese navigators had to overcome during their discoveries and more specifically of the dangers Portuguese sailors faced when trying to round the Cape of Storms.
